text: yeah yeah hi everyone orangeman
almost gone here the internet's busiest
music nerd and it's time
for a review of the new 100 tricks point
never album
magic 10 tricks point never this is the
latest lp from prolific composer
producer
sonic alchemist daniel lopeten aka
oneotrix point never this i believe
is his fourth full-length lp with the
legendary warp
records and the project seems like a
pretty huge concept for him an artistic
self-portrait of sorts maybe the
record's title flow and various
interludes are all deeply inspired by
the world
of radio pretty interesting we're
finally getting a deep dive on something
like this
especially considering the 10 tricks
point never name is a play
on a radio station's frequency numbers
anyway
now when i understood this was the
conceptual direction
of this new album that excited me
because personally i do
have a lot of passion for the world of
radio
ever since really i had a little boombox
that i could tape my favorite songs off
the airwaves with
i went on to do broadcasting school in
my teens
managed a college radio station interned
at stations with
various formats news talk just pop radio
i
interned at an npr station which i
stayed there for years
and when i was much younger i feel old
saying this
radio is always at least part of my
musical
diet from pop stations and top 40
stations
to rock and hip hop stations college
stations
community stations too one local to me
has some of the best and
cool obscure programming every month
wpkn
they rule i mean obviously the internet
is now the music powerhouse
of the modern era but i still do have a
personal soft spot for radio
and daniel's love of radio manifests
here
in a series of tracks that run a gamut
of sounds and aesthetics
that he's indulged in over the course of
his very long career
on this thing we get neo-psych ballads
ambient meditations
plunderphonic passages tracks that have
more pop leanings too
it's like we're getting the hits across
daniel's discography but
they're all filtered through this
nostalgic lens plus they're being
presented as if we are
slowly gliding from sound to sound like
their stations on a radio dial
i think you could only catch these vibes
in a radio market smack dab in the
middle of a
utopia future society or in a nostalgic
dream world in daniel's head
where he comes up with these pillowy
reinterpretations of
formative music experiences he's had
listening to the radio
now as i implied earlier the tracks on
this project
are a real mixed bag there's not a ton
of sonic and aesthetic cohesion
sometimes
outside of just trying to sound as
varied as possible
on paper i love the concept especially
since daniel is responsible for some of
my favorite records of the 2010s
and also considering the amount of
impact he's had on various music genres
over the years though there is a
shocking lack of vaporwave
on this thing but while i do love the
ideas behind this lp
i have to say i think the execution
leaves a lot to be desired
the result of going in this direction i
think is a track list with a very
fragmented flow
and with each song being in a somewhat
isolated state
there's not a lot of reinforcement of
anything here plus when looking at many
of these pieces on a micro level i don't
think daniel is necessarily dropping his
best work
in fact i don't love me anymore i think
is one of his worst
songs to date terrible vocal processing
over
a neo-psych mash of warbly sonic junk
mediocre tune 2 and stylistically it
sounds like kraut rock
meets pop punk meets tame impala
and some bad ai generated pop i guess
part of me appreciates the attempt to
make something that sounds like a
horrendously warped
memory but honestly it's just something
i'd rather forget
the rest of the track list sways between
songs that
either have pop or ambient leanings auto
and allo
features a lot of elaborate sound design
in the first leg
partially it sounds like a pop song
trying to
fight its way through competing radio
signals or something
eventually settling down into this
ambient ballad loaded with plucky tones
some eerie processed vocals too it's
pretty while it's on
but the very abrupt ending leaves me
sort of
cold the following long road home seems
almost like a continuation of the age of
era the synth strings the alien vocals
it's futuristic it's regal but maybe
with more of a pop edge
this time around which doesn't
necessarily make it that much more
interesting
bow echo is a short instrumental passage
that reads almost like
a r plus seven leftover but pieces of
its mix
are being fed through this really weak
radio signal it's grainy
it's distorted it's kind of veering in
and out of frame
meanwhile these distorted elements are
being smothered a little bit with these
euphoric synth swells it's not my
favorite cut here but it does have an
interesting mix of textures and does
provide a transitional moment for some
of the strongest ambient pieces on the
record
the multi-phased the weather channel for
example
does sound sort of like a weather
channel music bed
if it were broadcasting from again an
idyllic utopia where the weather year
round is a
perfect mild sunny 70 degrees
now there are some interesting and
unexpected passages that come
after this though including some
returnal-esque
drones as well as ambient noise and
chatter
then finally a hefty monotone nolan
b-roll in rap verse that takes things up
on the back end
that flows very lethargically over these
twittering beats that have a
real 80 sheen to them honestly it sounds
like something out of a dean
blunt record then the following no
nightmares reinforces
some of these aesthetics extending those
80s vibes into a blissful
wall of new ageisms propelled with
linear grooves and lead vocals from the
weekend
sure the melodies and structures are a
bit dodgy but the piece does still feel
like
you're listening to a memory come
together regardless a potent and
beautiful vibe
rings through and it still manages to be
a highlight for me
which was also the case for tales from
the trash
stratum which features a wonderful
display of sound play and texture
the curious sporadic ambient tones pops
delays there's quite a bit to it and yet
it feels like daniel is working with
eno's baseline concepts for ambient
music
but making them maximal for an
oversaturated
information age the plunderphonic intro
of imageo brings me back to daniel's
replica days as do the cycling swells of
tones that happen again and again and
again
they're wavy they're ghostly and they
get clearer and more intense with each
repetition
the track seems to tie into the record's
overall concept really well too
as the sounds seem to get more and more
distorted
like you're losing a radio signal as
this is happening these gorgeous
orchestral arrangements start
zooming in as if we are picking up a new
signal or something
like two different songs from two
different stations but somehow they're
working
together and harmonizing now the final
leg of the record i am a little mixed on
lost but never alone is yet another song
with a strong lead vocal that sounds
like it's
heavily warped as if it's coming off of
an old cassette but also coming off of a
bad radio signal
i think the manipulations are impressive
as are
the guitar solos and grand crescendo of
instrumentation at the end but at the
end of the day
i'm not very crazy about the song itself
then wave idea
almost feels like an odd man out on the
record because
not only does it lack some of the weird
aesthetic manipulations that so many
other songs here have
but it's really just a bland drone
marked with what sounds like birds
tweeting
as well as i guess cuckoo clocks going
off
but nothing special does end things off
on a relatively strong note it is a
somber piece of ambient balladry with
some of the most moving vocal melodies
on the entire record
in fact i would say this is one of the
better vocal performances despite all of
the heavy manipulations on this vocal
it still packs quite an emotional punch
meanwhile the
instrumental is orbited by all of these
sounds that seem almost
self-referential to earlier moments on
the record
to put it simply i'll say i enjoyed this
record but only a little bit
there are certainly some highlights here
and i love the concept i love the
ambition
of what daniel tried to do on this
record but i just don't think this
is his best material to date and
considering how retrospective this
project is supposed to be
it doesn't even cover as much ground in
daniel's back catalog
as it could or really should feeling a
decent two strong six
on this one transition have you given
this album a listen did you love it did
you hate it
what would you rate it you're the best
you're the best what should i review
